intro: Passerina truncata, commonly known as the cutleaf pasqueflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its basal leaves that are deeply lobed and often have a truncate or notched appearance. The plant produces showy, yellow flowers with numerous stamens, typically blooming in early spring. It thrives in open, rocky habitats and is adapted to dry, sunny conditions. Passerina truncata is often found in alpine and subalpine regions, where it plays a role in local ecosystems.
